text.title: Origins of US Racial Classifications
text.headline: When does the codification of race as a category of identity begin?
text.text: The U.S. government began keeping official records of racial classifications in the late 18th century. The first U.S. Census happened in 1790, not so coincidentally the same year that Congress passed the Naturalization Act, which restricted the right of adopted citizenship to "Free White" people only. These historical facts set the context leading to Susie Phipps' legal challenge to change her racial classification.

text.headline: Hypo-descent Law
text.text: In the State of Louisiana, a hypo-descent law passes. This law is based on the Colonial Era "one-drop rule," in which anyone with "a trace of Black ancestry" was declared Black. In Louisiana, the court specified that anyone with 1/32 nd or more African ancestry is considered Black.

text.headline: Passport Denied
text.text: At age 43, Phipps attempts to get a passport and is denied. Phipps checked "White" on her application, however this racial classification is inconsistent with her birth certificate, which indicates that her race is "Black" and the race of one her parents is "Colored."

text.headline: Pursuing a Legal Route
text.text: Phipps unsuccessfully sues the Louisiana Bureau of Vital Records to change her classification from "Black" to "White." During the trial, a Tulane University professor testifies on her behalf that most Whites have 1/20 th African ancestry.

text.headline: Racial Lineage
text.text: Phipps's great-great-great-great grandmother [Margarita] was revealed to have been a slave. In a 1983 interview, Phipps was quoted that she came to believe that "Margarita had been dARK rather than Black."

text.headline: Racial Complexities
text.text: Upon learning about her racial classification, Phipps reported to have been "sick for three days." Phipps claims she held no grudge against Blacks, and she was only standing up for what she believed: she was White.

text.headline: US Supreme Court Appeals
text.text: The Louisiana 1/32 nd statute was abolished in 1983, and a "traceable amount" statute replaced it, leaving Phipps still unable to change her racial classification. Phipps appealed to the US Supreme Court twice. Both appeals were unsuccessful and the court has since upheld the law by its "traceable amount" criteria.
